Award.AwardTitle: Testing a Model of Instructor Feedback to Improve College Students' Success in Calculus
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving success in college mathematics. To do so, it will develop and implement specific instructor feedback strategies that are expected to increase student learning and success in introductory college calculus courses. Introductory college calculus is a gateway course that enrolls hundreds of thousands of students across the nation each year. Many of these students aspire to major in a STEM field. Students' experiences in calculus can have a significant impact on their interest and persistence in pursuing those aspirations, particularly for students from underrepresented populations, including women, racial minorities, first-generation college students, and those from low socioeconomic backgrounds. Students in these populations leave STEM degree programs at a higher rate than their peers. The loss of students from STEM majors has far-reaching consequences for the students' educational attainment and career prospects. However, it also limits the potential of the STEM enterprise to benefit from the advantages of diversity for problem solving, innovation, and other outcomes. This project focuses on instructor feedback to students as a potentially transformative, relatively low-cost instructional tool to improve the undergraduate STEM experience, particularly for students from underrepresented groups. Certain types of feedback may boost students' confidence in their ability and belonging in math, which in turn may shape their study habits, academic help-seeking behaviors, and attitudes toward, identification with, and interest in math and related fields. Over time, these subtle changes may contribute to improved performance and persistence in math, as reflected by students' calculus course grades and future enrollment in STEM courses. By defining the types of feedback that are most effective for improving math outcomes, the project will produce information that will be immediately useful to mathematics educators and that may apply in other STEM fields.

Using survey methods, researchers will first investigate current norms, practices, and experiences surrounding feedback in introductory college calculus courses. Next, using experimental methods, students in introductory calculus courses will be randomly assigned to receive different types of feedback to determine which are most beneficial, and whether aspects of the feedback provider and student status matter in shaping the outcomes. Four types of feedback will be examined: Objective feedback (providing only a grade or score), and three types of descriptive feedback: Positive feedback (conveying a job well done), Corrective feedback (conveying what could be improved), and Wise feedback (corrective feedback plus assurance that students can meet high standards). Students will complete four surveys over the course of the semester, examining measures including self-efficacy and belonging in math, study habits, academic help-seeking behaviors, attitudes/identification/interest in math, and performance and persistence in math (i.e., calculus grades, future enrollment in STEM courses). By examining existing norms and practices and testing the types of feedback that are most beneficial for students, this project could improve the mindsets and practices of instructors in these courses. Findings from the project may provide guides for improving the design and implementation of feedback protocols in math classrooms, which in turn may improve the educational experience for students, especially students that may have increased risk of leaving STEM degree programs. The researchers will disseminate results of this project widely to math educators, college administrators, academics, and the public by publishing the findings in journals, presenting at conferences, conducting instructor workshops, and creating an online feedback training course for math instructors on how to give feedback. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined current norms, practices, and consequences of giving different types of feedback to students in introductory college math courses in the U.S. Undergraduate students’ experiences in gateway courses, such as introductory calculus, play a key role in shaping their academic self-perceptions, motivation, and performance in STEM. This project focused on positive feedback as a useful tool to improve the undergraduate STEM experience.

        Studies 1a and 1b documented existing norms, practices, and experiences surrounding the culture of feedback-giving in introductory college calculus courses. Study 1a examined instructors’ reports of feedback-giving and found the perceived norm in Math Departments across the U.S. is to give objective feedback (i.e., reporting students’ score only), but not positive feedback (i.e., conveying a job well done). Instructors’ feedback-giving practices mirrored these norms; instructors reported giving positive feedback less often in math (vs. English) courses.

         Study 1b examined college students’ reports of instructors’ feedback-giving practices and the anticipated impact of these practices on their academic self-perceptions. Students reported receiving less positive (vs. objective) feedback in their math (vs. English) courses. However, all students said they would have benefitted from receiving positive feedback in their math (vs. English) courses. In particular, women said they would have felt greater self-efficacy, belonging, and motivation to succeed if they had received positive feedback from their male math instructors.

         Overall, Studies 1a and 1b reveal a mismatch between current norms and practices of giving feedback in math courses and the feedback types that are most effective for students. Although students say receiving positive feedback in their math courses would be beneficial, the current norm and practice is for instructors not to give such feedback.

         The next set of studies (Studies 2a-2d) examined the impact of giving different types of feedback to students taking introductory college calculus courses at the University at Buffalo (UB) and University of Oklahoma (OU). In Study 2a, math instructors were trained to give either objective feedback (i.e., students’ exam score only) or positive feedback (i.e., students’ score plus a positive comment corresponding to “Great job!” “Good job!” “Good try!” or “Keep trying!” depending on exam performance).

         Students randomly assigned to receive positive (vs. objective) feedback on Exam 1 reported greater intentions to adopt proactive study habits, which predicted higher final math grades. After receiving positive (vs. objective) feedback on Exam 2, students reported greater belonging in math, which predicted more favorable attitudes toward, identification with, and interest in STEM. Students who received positive feedback on Exam 2 also reported greater math self-efficacy, which predicted higher final math grades. These latter results were strongest among racial-ethnic minority students.

         Study 2b examined effects of giving corrective feedback (conveying what could be improved) versus objective feedback to students in college calculus courses. Those who received corrective feedback on Exam 1 reported lower math self-efficacy, which predicted less favorable STEM attitudes/identity/ interest. Study 2c examined effects of giving wise feedback (corrective feedback plus assurance that students can meet high standards) versus objective feedback to students in college calculus courses. Those who received wise feedback on Exam 1 reported greater intended math study habits, which predicted more favorable STEM attitudes/identity/ interest.

          Finally, Study 2d compared positive versus wise versus objective feedback. Students rated positive feedback as more supportive, encouraging, and less condescending and patronizing than objective feedback or wise feedback. After receiving positive feedback on Exam 2, students felt greater math belonging, which predicted more favorable STEM attitudes/identity/interest at the end of the semester.

          Overall, this project advances knowledge and understanding of current norms and practices of feedback-giving in introductory college calculus courses and how different types of feedback shape students’ STEM-related outcomes.

        This project was a collaboration between three faculty from two large universities: Dr. Lora Park (PI, UB, Department of Psychology), Dr. Joseph Hundley (Co-PI, UB, Department of Mathematics), and Dr. Deborah Moore-Russo (Co-PI, OU, Department of Mathematics). Each team member developed and refined the instructor feedback protocols and study materials, helped to recruit and train math instructors, and provided input on the results and manuscript. 

        Findings from this project were accepted for publication (Park et al., in press). The PI and Co-PI gave many presentations of this work including 2 posters, 8 conference talks (e.g., at the Joint Mathematics Meetings, national and international psychology conferences), 8 invited talks at universities across the U.S. and Canada, and 2 virtual presentations (e.g., Research in Undergraduate Math Education Seminar at OU; Inclusive Active Learning in Introductory Mathematics Courses hosted by the Mathematical Association of America and University of Colorado-Boulder). Ultimately, this project demonstrates the far-reaching impact of a low-cost feedback tool to improve students’ STEM experiences, especially those from underrepresented groups.

Park, L.E., Ward, D.E., Moore-Russo, D., Rickard, B., Vessels, V., & Hundley, J. (in press). Positive feedback as a lever to boost students’ STEM outcomes. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin.
